# hmpps-official-visits-ui

[![repo standards badge](https://img.shields.io/endpoint?labelColor=231f20&color=005ea5&style=flat&label=MoJ%20Compliant&url=https%3A%2F%2Foperations-engineering-reports-prod.cloud-platform.service.justice.gov.uk%2Fapi%2Fv1%2Fcompliant_public_repositories%2Fendpoint%2Fhmpps-official-visits-ui&logo=data:image/png;base64,)](https://operations-engineering-reports-prod.cloud-platform.service.justice.gov.uk/public-report/hmpps-official-visits-ui)
[![Docker Repository on ghcr](https://img.shields.io/badge/ghcr.io-repository-2496ED.svg?logo=docker)](https://ghcr.io/ministryofjustice/hmpps-official-visits-ui)

Official Visits UI

# Instructions

This is the user interface service for booking and managing official visits in DPS.

Our security policy is located [here](https://github.com/ministryofjustice/hmpps-official-visits-ui/security/policy).

## Building the service

There are several ways to start the service. The most common is to run the UI and a REDIS container locally, but
rely on the Cloud Platform DEV environment for all other dependencies.

```bash
npm install
npm run build
```

## Setting up a local .env file (to provide essential configuration values)

Create a file `.env` in the root of your project clone. This file is in .gitignore, so should never be committed.
It should have the following contents, but see your team for the actual values they are set to.

```bash
AUTH_CODE_CLIENT_ID=<ask>
AUTH_CODE_CLIENT_SECRET=<ask>
CLIENT_CREDS_CLIENT_ID=<ask>
CLIENT_CREDS_CLIENT_SECRET=<ask>
HMPPS_AUTH_URL=<ask>
```
For the full content of the .env file please request from the developers on the team.

## Running the unit tests

```bash
npm run test
```

### Dependencies

### HMPPS Auth

To allow authenticated users to access your application, even locally, you will need to reference a running
instance of `hmpps-auth`. This can be local in a docker container, but more usually you would reference
a running instance in the Cloud Platform dev environment, by setting the environment variable `HMPPS_AUTH_API_URL`
and providing this via an environment variable in your `.env` file.

### REDIS

When deployed to an environment with multiple pods we run applications with an instance of REDIS/Elasticache to provide
a distributed cache of user session data. When running locally, the service also needs access to a REDIS instance, and usually
this is provided via a local docker container. It can be configured not to use REDIS if required.

## Running the service locally

Pull and start a REDIS docker container.
```bash
docker-compose pull && docker-compose up - d
```

Start the server in dev mode
```bash
npm run start:dev
```
This will start the service in dev mode (detecting changes and restarting as necessary) accessible at http://localhost:3000

### Logging in

Once the application is running you should then be able to log in with any user account with the appropriate role in
the development environment.

### Run linter

* `npm run lint` runs `eslint`.
* `npm run typecheck` runs the TypeScript compiler `tsc`.

### Running integration tests

Integration tests (using Cypress) can be run against the UI and need an extra dependency to mock out any
API calls that will be made during the tests. This is done with Wiremock running locally in a container.

There is a 3-step process:
* Run wiremock container
* Run the service in integration test mode
* Run the Cypress test tool

Start wiremock with:

`docker-compose -f docker-compose-test.yml up -d`

Run the service in integration test mode with:

`npm run start-feature` (it will tie-up one terminal)

And then either, run tests in headless mode with:

`npm run int-test`

Or run tests with the cypress UI:

`npm run int-test-ui`

## Change log

A changelog for the service is available [here](./CHANGELOG.md)
